question_paper.question_paper_description: 2024 Sep01: IIT M FN EXAM QDF1

questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL : BUSINESS ANALYTICS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"  ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DIPLOMA LEVEL : BUSINESS ANALYTICS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)"  ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN.  (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: The computed p-value of a chi-square goodness-of-fit test is 0.067. Then, which of the following statements are TRUE
question_texts: The computed p-value of a chi-square goodness-of-fit test is 0.067. Then, which of the following statements are TRUE

options.option_text: At a 5% level of significance, the null hypothesis is rejected
At a 5% level of significance, the null hypothesis is not-rejected
At a 10% level of significance, the null hypothesis is rejected
At a 10% level of significance, the null hypothesis is not-rejected
At a 5% level of significance, the alternative hypothesis is rejected
At a 5% level of significance, the alternative hypothesis is not-rejected
At a 10% level of significance, the alternative hypothesis is rejected
At a 10% level of significance, the alternative hypothesis is not-rejected
None of these

questions.question_text_1: The objective function of the linear programming model using pair-wise judgments:
question_texts: The objective function of the linear programming model using pair-wise judgments:

options.option_text: Maximize the distance from the ideal point
Minimize the distance from the ideal point
Minimize the poorness of fit
Both Maximize the distance from the ideal point & Minimize the poorness of fit
Both Minimize the distance from the ideal point & Minimize the poorness of fit

questions.question_text_1: In the below diagram, the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following are true?
questions.question_text_2: In the below diagram, the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following are true?
question_texts: In the below diagram, the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following are true?
In the below diagram, the customer wants to decide between the products O1 & O2, and x denotes the coordinates of the ideal product. Which of the following are true?

options.option_text: Customers will prefer O1 when d2>d1
Customers will prefer O2 when d1<d2
Both Customers will prefer O1 when d2>d1 & Customers will prefer O2 whend1<d2
None of these

questions.question_text_1: Assume 5 factories are producing the same output of 1000 units. But, the resources used i.e. labour and raw materials are different. Which of the following factories are efficient?
questions.question_text_2: Assume 5 factories are producing the same output of 1000 units. But, the resources used i.e. labour and raw materials are different. Which of the following factories are efficient?
question_texts: Assume 5 factories are producing the same output of 1000 units. But, the resources used i.e. labour and raw materials are different. Which of the following factories are efficient?
Assume 5 factories are producing the same output of 1000 units. But, the resources used i.e. labour and raw materials are different. Which of the following factories are efficient?

options.option_text: A, B, D
B, C, D
A, C, D
A, E, D
B, D, E

questions.question_text_1: In a conjoint problem with 4 products and 2 attributes, how many pair-wise preferences are possible?
question_texts: In a conjoint problem with 4 products and 2 attributes, how many pair-wise preferences are possible?

questions.question_text_1: If the attribute values in the conjoint analysis is a continuous variable and the data is collected in a pairwise order, then what approach can be used:
question_texts: If the attribute values in the conjoint analysis is a continuous variable and the data is collected in a pairwise order, then what approach can be used:

options.option_text: Optimization approach
Regression approach
Statistical approach
Optimization approach or Statistical approach

questions.question_text_1: There are 6 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 5 has obtained an efficiency of 0.7 and business unit 6 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct?
question_texts: There are 6 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 5 has obtained an efficiency of 0.7 and business unit 6 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.option_text: Business unit 5 will be efficient
Business unit 6 will be efficient
Business unit 5 will be inefficient
Business unit 6 will be inefficient

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are true:
question_texts: Which of the following are true:

options.option_text: Productive efficiency frontiers are all combinations of outputs such that theproduction of one unit cannot be increased without sacrificing without sacrificing the other.
Organizations that do not find themselves on the Economic frontier are calledinefficient economic units or organizations.
Productive efficiency focuses on maximizing the given output under givenconstraints without focusing on optimally allocating the products.
DEA focuses on the technology to improve the productive efficiency.

questions.question_text_1: What is the format of data needed for performing the conjoint analysis using the Statistical or Linear Regression Approach?
question_texts: What is the format of data needed for performing the conjoint analysis using the Statistical or Linear Regression Approach?

options.option_text: Consumer Choice Data is Ratings
Consumer Choice Data is Pairwise Comparison
Value of the attributes are continuous
Value of the product attributes are categorical

questions.question_text_1: DMS lighting produces 3 types of bulbs (Type-A, Type-B and Type-C). The probability that a Type-A bulb will give more than 100 hours (>= 100 hours) of life is 0.7, with the corresponding probabilities of Type-B and Type-C bulbs being 0.4 and 0.3 respectively. In any production, 20% of the bulbs are of Type-A, 30% are of Type-B and 50% are of Type-C. Then answer the given subquestions
question_texts: DMS lighting produces 3 types of bulbs (Type-A, Type-B and Type-C). The probability that a Type-A bulb will give more than 100 hours (>= 100 hours) of life is 0.7, with the corresponding probabilities of Type-B and Type-C bulbs being 0.4 and 0.3 respectively. In any production, 20% of the bulbs are of Type-A, 30% are of Type-B and 50% are of Type-C. Then answer the given subquestions

questions.question_text_1: What is the probability that a bulb from the production lot will give a life of more than 100 hours? (Note: Input your answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if your answer is “1.235” then enter the answer as “1.24”)

questions.question_text_1: DMS is giving a replacement warranty for bulbs that last for less than 100 hours of life. The replacement will cost Rs. 2 for every Type-A bulb, Rs. 1.75 for every Type-B bulb and Rs. 3 for every Type-C bulb. Then, if 10,000 bulbs are produced and sold in a year, what would be the total warranty related cost that DMS will expect to incur? (Note: Input your answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if your answer is “1.235” then enter the answer as “1.24”)
question_texts: DMS is giving a replacement warranty for bulbs that last for less than 100 hours of life. The replacement will cost Rs. 2 for every Type-A bulb, Rs. 1.75 for every Type-B bulb and Rs. 3 for every Type-C bulb. For example, if your answer is “1.235” then enter the answer as “1.24”)

questions.question_text_1: There are 5 business units where we measure the efficiency based on two outputs and one input. You are solving the optimization problem for business unit 4 and you find that the efficiency is 0.8. You find that the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 3 and 5 are non-zero and the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of other units are zero. The dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 3 and 5 are 0.5 and 0.3 respectively. You are given the following table where sales and loyal customers are the two outputs. Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Dr. Milo wants to advertise his new brand of tuition centres called “Torture Students”. Currently promotion plans are underway for this year’s admission. Advertising alternatives include TV, Radio and Social Media. The estimated audiences per advertisement (who will enrol after viewing the advertisement) and costs per advertisement for the different alternatives are shown in Table-2. To ensure a balanced use of advertisement media (1) radio advertisements must not exceed 70% of the total number of advertisements authorised (2) amount authorised for TV advertisements should account for at least 30% of the total spending (3) Amount of spending on social media advertisements cannot exceed more than 25% of the other two spending. The promotional budget is limited to Rs. 1,82,000, and Dr. Milo wants to use all the available money to maximize the number of enrolments. Then answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Diploma in Business Analytics (Computer-Based Exam)** based on the provided question paper.
The exam covers **statistics, optimization, decision analysis, classification metrics, and linear programming (LP)**.
---

---

### **1. Hypothesis Testing (Chi-Square Goodness-of-Fit Test)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Null Hypothesis (H₀):** Assumes no association between categorical variables (e.g., independence of sales across stores).
- **Alternative Hypothesis (H₁):** Assumes an association exists.
- **p-value:** Probability of observing the data if H₀ is true.
  - If **p-value < α (significance level)**, reject H₀.
  - If **p-value ≥ α**, fail to reject H₀.
- **Degrees of Freedom (df):**
  For a contingency table with **r rows** and **c columns**:
  \[
  df = (r - 1)(c - 1)
  \]
- **Expected Frequency (E):**
  For cell in row *i* and column *j*:
  \[
  E_{ij} = \frac{(\text{Row Total}_i) \times (\text{Column Total}_j)}{\text{Grand Total}}
  \]
- **Chi-Square Statistic:**
  \[
  \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_{ij} - E_{ij})^2}{E_{ij}}
  \]
  where \(O_{ij}\) = observed frequency, \(E_{ij}\) = expected frequency.

#### **Decision Rules:**
| **Significance Level (α)** | **p-value** | **Decision**               |
|----------------------------|-------------|----------------------------|
| 5% (0.05)                  | 0.067       | **Fail to reject H₀**      |
| 10% (0.10)                 | 0.067       | **Fail to reject H₀**      |

---

### **2. Conjoint Analysis**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Objective:** Determine consumer preferences for product attributes.
- **Pairwise Comparisons:**
  - For **n products**, number of pairwise comparisons = \( \frac{n(n-1)}{2} \).
  - Example: 4 products → \( \frac{4 \times 3}{2} = 6 \) comparisons.
- **Approaches:**
  - **Optimization Approach:** Used when attributes are **continuous** (e.g., minimizing distance from ideal point).
  - **Regression Approach:** Used when attributes are **categorical** and consumer choice data is **ratings-based**.
- **Ideal Point Model:**
  - Consumers prefer products **closest to their ideal** (minimize distance \(d\)).
  - If \(d_1 < d_2\), prefer product 1 over product 2.

---

### **3. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Efficiency Measurement:** Compares **Decision-Making Units (DMUs)** (e.g., factories, business units) based on **inputs/outputs**.
- **Efficiency Score:**
  - **1.0 = Efficient** (lies on the frontier).
  - **<1.0 = Inefficient** (can improve by reducing inputs or increasing outputs).
- **Dual Variables (Weights):**
  - Non-zero weights indicate **peer groups** (e.g., BU 3 and BU 5 influence BU 4’s efficiency).
- **Productive Efficiency Frontier:**
  - Combination of outputs where **no output can be increased without sacrificing another**.
- **Economic Efficiency:**
  - DMUs **not on the frontier** are inefficient.

#### **Example (Factory Efficiency):**
| Factory | Labour (Input) | Raw Material (Input) | **Efficient?** |
|---------|----------------|----------------------|----------------|
| A       | 100            | 171                  | Yes            |
| B       | 105            | 175                  | No             |
| C       | 108            | 162                  | Yes            |
| D       | 104            | 165                  | Yes            |
| E       | 109            | 170                  | No             |

**Efficient Factories:** A, C, D (use fewer resources for same output).

---

### **4. Linear Programming (LP)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Objective Function:** Maximize/minimize a linear expression (e.g., maximize enrolments).
- **Constraints:** Linear inequalities (e.g., budget limits, balanced media usage).
- **Dual Problem:**
  - Converts primal constraints to dual variables.
  - Number of dual constraints = number of primal variables (and vice versa).
- **Feasibility:**
  - A solution satisfies **all constraints**.
  - Example: Dr. Milo’s budget allocation must meet:
    1. Radio ads ≤ 70% of total ads.
    2. TV spending ≥ 30% of total budget.
    3. Social media spending ≤ 25% of (TV + Radio) spending.

#### **Primal-Dual Relationships:**
| **Primal**               | **Dual**                     |
|--------------------------|------------------------------|
| *n* variables             | *n* constraints               |
| *m* constraints           | *m* variables                 |
| Maximization             | Minimization (and vice versa) |

#### **Example (Advertising Problem):**
- **Decision Variables:** Number of ads in TV (\(x_1\)), Radio (\(x_2\)), Social Media (\(x_3\)).
- **Objective:** Maximize enrolments:
  \[
  \text{Max } Z = 4000x_1 + 1800x_2 + 10000x_3
  \]
- **Constraints:**
  1. Budget: \(2500x_1 + 400x_2 + 750x_3 \leq 182000\).
  2. Radio ads: \(x_2 \leq 0.7(x_1 + x_2 + x_3)\).
  3. TV spending: \(2500x_1 \geq 0.3(2500x_1 + 400x_2 + 750x_3)\).
  4. Social media spending: \(750x_3 \leq 0.25(2500x_1 + 400x_2)\).

---

### **5. Probability (Bayes’ Theorem, Expected Value)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Total Probability:**
  \[
  P(\text{>100 hours}) = P(A)P(\text{>100}|A) + P(B)P(\text{>100}|B) + P(C)P(\text{>100}|C)
  \]
  Example:
  \[
  P(\text{>100}) = 0.2 \times 0.7 + 0.3 \times 0.4 + 0.5 \times 0.3 = 0.41
  \]
- **Bayes’ Theorem:**
  \[
  P(B|\text{>100}) = \frac{P(B)P(\text{>100}|B)}{P(\text{>100})} = \frac{0.3 \times 0.4}{0.41} \approx 0.293
  \]
- **Expected Cost:**
  \[
  \text{Total Cost} = n \times [P(A)P(\text{<100}|A)C_A + P(B)P(\text{<100}|B)C_B + P(C)P(\text{<100}|C)C_C]
  \]
  Example (for 10,000 bulbs):
  \[
  \text{Cost} = 10000 \times [0.2 \times 0.3 \times 2 + 0.3 \times 0.6 \times 1.75 + 0.5 \times 0.7 \times 3] \approx 14850
  \]

---

### **6. Classification Metrics**
#### **Key Terms:**
| **Metric**       | **Formula**                                                                 | **Interpretation**                          |
|------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|
| **Accuracy**     | \(\frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN}\)                                      | Overall correctness.                       |
| **Precision**    | \(\frac{TP}{TP + FP}\) (for Class 1)                                      | % of predicted positives that are actual.  |
| **Recall**       | \(\frac{TP}{TP + FN}\) (for Class 1)                                      | % of actual positives correctly predicted. |
| **Sensitivity**  | Same as Recall.                                                            |                                            |
| **Specificity**  | \(\frac{TN}{TN + FP}\) (for Class 0)                                      | % of actual negatives correctly predicted. |

#### **Example (Visa Classification):**
| **Actual \ Predicted** | **Granted (1)** | **Not Granted (0)** |
|------------------------|------------------|---------------------|
| **Granted (1)**       | TP = 6           | FN = 3              |
| **Not Granted (0)**   | FP = 4           | TN = 5              |

- **Accuracy:** \(\frac{6 + 5}{6 + 5 + 4 + 3} = \frac{11}{18} \approx 61.1\%\).
- **Precision (Class 1):** \(\frac{6}{6 + 4} = 60\%\).
- **Recall (Class 1):** \(\frac{6}{6 + 3} \approx 66.7\%\).

---

### **7. Efficiency Calculation (DEA)**
#### **Key Equations:**
- **Efficiency Score (θ):**
  \[
  \theta = \frac{\text{Weighted Sum of Outputs}}{\text{Weighted Sum of Inputs}}
  \]
  Example: For BU 4 with efficiency = 0.8 and peers BU 3 (weight = 0.5) and BU 5 (weight = 0.3):
  \[
  \text{Sales}_4 = 0.8 \times (0.5 \times 12000 + 0.3 \times 10000) \approx 11250
  \]
  \[
  \text{Loyal Customers}_4 = 0.8 \times (0.5 \times 100 + 0.3 \times 120) \approx 108
  \]

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Hypothesis Testing & Chi-Square**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Hypothesis Testing] --> B[Null Hypothesis H₀]
    A --> C[Alternative Hypothesis H₁]
    B --> D[p-value]
    C --> D
    D --> E[Compare to α]
    E --> F[Reject H₀ if p < α]
    E --> G[Fail to Reject H₀ if p ≥ α]
    A --> H[Chi-Square Test]
    H --> I[Expected Frequency]
    H --> J[Degrees of Freedom]
    I --> K[O vs. E]
    J --> K
    K --> D
```

#### **Graph 2: Conjoint Analysis**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Conjoint Analysis] --> B[Pairwise Comparisons]
    A --> C[Optimization Approach]
    A --> D[Regression Approach]
    B --> E[n Products → n(n-1)/2 Pairs]
    C --> F[Continuous Attributes]
    D --> G[Categorical Attributes]
    F --> H[Minimize Distance to Ideal]
    G --> I[Ratings Data]
```

#### **Graph 3: Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[DEA] --> B[Efficiency Score θ]
    A --> C[Inputs/Outputs]
    B --> D[θ = 1.0 → Efficient]
    B --> E[θ < 1.0 → Inefficient]
    C --> F[Peer Groups]
    F --> G[Dual Variables]
    G --> H[Non-Zero Weights]
    H --> D
```

#### **Graph 4: Linear Programming**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Linear Programming] --> B[Primal Problem]
    A --> C[Dual Problem]
    B --> D[Objective Function]
    B --> E[Constraints]
    C --> F[Variables = Primal Constraints]
    C --> G[Constraints = Primal Variables]
    D --> H[Maximize/Minimize]
    E --> I[Feasible Region]
    I --> J[Optimal Solution]
```

#### **Graph 5: Classification Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Classification Metrics] --> B[Confusion Matrix]
    B --> C[True Positives TP]
    B --> D[False Positives FP]
    B --> E[True Negatives TN]
    B --> F[False Negatives FN]
    A --> G[Accuracy]
    A --> H[Precision]
    A --> I[Recall]
    A --> J[Specificity]
    G --> K[TP + TN / Total]
    H --> L[TP / TP + FP]
    I --> M[TP / TP + FN]
    J --> N[TN / TN + FP]
```

#### **Graph 6: Probability & Bayes’ Theorem**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Probability] --> B[Total Probability]
    A --> C[Bayes' Theorem]
    B --> D[P Event = Σ P Condition × P Event | Condition]
    C --> E[P Condition | Event = P Condition × P Event | Condition / P Event]
    A --> F[Expected Value]
    F --> G[Cost Calculation]
    G --> H[Weighted Sum]
```
